Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling the Reionization of the Intergalactic Medium
Award.AbstractNarration:
Reionization is the epoch during which intergalactic hydrogen was ionized, the period when the first galaxies formed and when the intergalactic gas was significantly heated, to tens of thousands of degrees Kelvin, but despite its importance, little is known definitively about this phase transition. This project aims to resolve the impact of self-shielding systems, perhaps the largest still unquantified uncertainty in current models of reionization, through a rigorous program of numerical simulations. Prior radiative transfer simulations did not have the resolution to capture self-shielding systems, and thus misestimated the total number of recombinations, biasing their predictions for the duration of reionization.

Starting with a physically motivated model that includes self-shielding regions and explores parameter space with relatively inexpensive simulations, the work will use those results to carry out the first simulations with sufficient resolution to resolve self-shielding systems. Those simulations will verify the results from the initial work, and will be a resource for statistical studies on the structure of reionization. This study will understand how the violent relaxation of gas from photoheating during reionization influences dense gas and, hence, self-shielding systems, and will generally aid the interpretation of all observations of the reionization era.

The data set of state-of-the-art reionization simulations will be made public and can be analyzed by the scientific community. Past work by this team has been used in many unaffiliated studies and the new results should also be of great utility. Similarly, the publicly available archive of visualizations will both educate the public and help to develop scientists? intuition. Supported undergraduate researchers will be drawn preferentially from under-represented groups, and the researchers intend public lectures at schools and other venues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cosmic reionization is a milestone event in cosmic history when the first stars, galaxies, and quasars ionized and heated the intergalactic hydrogen and helium gas. Studying this period, known as the epoch of reionization, can reveal how the first generation of luminous objects formed and evolved. Current observations and theory suggest that hydrogen reionization was completed by the time the Universe was a billion years old, while helium reionization occurred later within the first three or four billion years. However, there are many remaining questions on these complex processes.

This project developed and applied state-of-the-art cosmological simulations to study reionization in comparison with existing observations. We used a suite of high-resolution N-body simulations to quantify the connection between galaxies, quasars, and dark matter halos in order to understand the properties and abundance of the major sources of ionizing radiation. Building on this work, we then used a suite of radiation-hydrodynamic simulations to study how galaxies and quasars ionized and heated the hydrogen and helium gas. We made theoretical predictions and mock observations of various observational signatures from the intergalactic gas.

The intellual merits include improvements in cosmological codes, simulations, and understanding of cosmic reionization. The RadHydro code for simulating the evolution of dark matter, cosmic gas, and radiation was modified to run on supercomputers such as Blacklight and Bridges at the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center. We developed physically-motivated and observationally-constrained model for the evolving abundance of galaxies, and forecasted galaxy counts for the upcoming James Webb Space Telescope. We showed that observations of hydrogen absorption are consistent with temperature fluctuations from hydrogen reionization. However, we find that the imprints of helium reionization are more difficult to observe through these observations.

Co-PI Hy Trac at Carnegie Mellon University worked collaboratively with Co-PI Matthew McQuinn and postdoctoral fellow Anson D'Aloisio at the University of Washington. He has advised graduate student Paul La Plante at Carnegie Mellon University and some of the work is part of a PhD thesis on "Large-Scale Simulations of Hydrogen and Helium Reionization". The research results have been shared with the scientific community through 7 peer-reviewed publications and over 10 presentations at universities and conferences.

The broader impacts of the project include public outreach and education of students. Co-PI Trac was a volunteer cosmologist at the White House Frontiers Conference Astronomy Night at the Alleghney Observatory. He has also given a public talks on "Simulating the Universe with Supercomputers", a demonstration on "Scales of the Solar System" for Colfax public school students, and a storytelling on a "Journey through the Solar System" to preschoolers at the Early Childhood Development Center in Pittsburgh.
